text: Also Jesse Norman and Nick Hurd, both senior to Kwasi if not Cox.

text: Actually it’s probably Kwasi. Unless anyone else comes to mind.

text: Country is always best left to classicists. Though not Boris, obviously. Wonder who the next most prominent classicist in Parliament is?

text: But I thought we’d learnt by now that the public is always wrong. Anyway, it’s surely time for Grayling to be PM
author: patrick_kidd

text: And Corbyn will still be leader of the opposition, while the Tories argue over Europe
author: patrick_kidd

text: Ten of our 54 PMs have had monosyllable surnames, included three of the past four. A good omen for Gove. Or Rudd. Or Alan Mak.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I refer the honourable gentleman to the answer Mr Urquhart was fond of giving.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I think that means I have more chance of my bet on Lidders paying out than my one on Pike

text: George Melly told me near the end of his life that Buffy was one of the few things that gave him pleasure

text: No, it’s an old photo, I’ve had a beard for two years, though I don’t think I was thinner then, just more flattering angle.

text: And disturbingly the TLS has had more amusing stories than the Radio Times the past six months
author: patrick_kidd

text: Because it’s not an official role and generally just given as a meaningless sop title to soothe ego or for expedient. Clegg’s the only DPM since 2007. Major didn’t have one for first five years. Between 1955-89 the only DPM was Rab Butler for 15 months
author: patrick_kidd

text: May is *such* a geographer.... (have no idea what I mean by that, just being a snob)
author: patrick_kidd

text: If it were Lidington, it would be the first Cambridge-educated PM since Baldwin in 1937 and only the second PhD after Brown. If it were Gove would be the first PM with an English degree.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I had him at 100...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Little-known fact, our potential next prime minister’s PhD supervisor was Ben Elton’s uncle.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I’m setting @HackBlackburn the merry Sunday task of reading David Lidington’s PhD thesis and seeing if there are any jokes or good anecdotes in it https://www.history.ac.uk/history-online/theses/thesis/enforcement-penal-statutes-court-exchequer-c1558-c1576 …
author: patrick_kidd

text: Am I right in thinking that Trump doesn’t even have a White House pet? The first president not to? Lunatic.
author: patrick_kidd

text: People mock smashed avocado on toast but if Miliband had ordered that none of this would have happened
author: patrick_kidd

text: Isn’t the answer to our political problems obvious? Force May out and install @Number10cat as acting prime minister and chief mouser. I’d like to see Brussels get one over on Larry, the only mogg that matters
author: patrick_kidd

text: I certainly hope so...
author: patrick_kidd

author: patrick_kidd

text: Me too...
author: patrick_kidd

text: At what point did the majority of people lose the ability to spell “lose” correctly? I see it with two Os so often. And if the pronunciation foxes them, why don’t they also write “remoove”?
author: patrick_kidd

text: The last few years would have been much better if it had been Nancy Cameron who left her father in the pub and no one went back to get him.
author: patrick_kidd

text: "good enough to be true" is the diarist's mantra.
author: patrick_kidd

text: It's certainly true that they last sat on a Saturday in 1982 to debate the Falklands. And it is also true they finished at 2pm. It was a former MP who told me they wanted to be done in time for the Grand National and who am I to doubt a politician if it's a good story?
author: patrick_kidd

text: I didn’t feel much menace directly from those taking part but the narrative is clearly embedded in the groupthink. And talk of MPs facing repercussions is a bit chilling
author: patrick_kidd

text: That’s not good at all. But i don’t know anything about the Bury Place gridlock. A protest?
author: patrick_kidd

text: Oh very good

author: patrick_kidd

text: Well he likes peas, allegedly... Is he really a veggie?

text: The good news in delaying Brexit judgment day to April 12 is that John Major and Norman Tebbit, who respectively turn 76 and 88 on March 29, can now go out for a birthday dinner together and the conversation over the côte de boeuf won’t be too awkward.

text: Drinks on me.
author: patrick_kidd

text: He has very poor eyesight. I recall he had a detached retina or something and almost lost his sight. Suspect that’s why the writing is so big but he’ll have dictated the text.

author: patrick_kidd

text: Almost certainly. Muting you now. Have fun.

text: Don’t follow me then. Though I’ve given the Tories plenty of kicking. You just mean you only want criticism of them.

text: On the plus side at least Theresa May doesn’t walk out of meetings just because there’s someone there who doesn’t like her. Otherwise cabinet would never meet.

text: “Fuck it, I’m taking back power.” And a nation would breathe a sigh of relief.

text: We’re going to be spending the next nine days and three hours staring at this sodding Downing St lectern aren’t we, until Brexit just happens? Still, less wooden than watching May
author: patrick_kidd

text: To be fair if I was going to start a neoliberal metropolitan elite from scratch then a decent cheeseboard would be near the top of my must-have list. Plus a good gin menu. And olives.

text: Most MPs work weekends already. They just don't sit in the House of Commons and debate something that has already been debated to death.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I'll be watching rugby
author: patrick_kidd

text: I was a little off with that tweet, they actually broke at 2pm not 2.30, but was told it was for the National. Hansard debate here: https://api.parliament.uk/historic-hansard/commons/1982/apr/03/falkland-islands …
author: patrick_kidd

text: I suspect that despite my reasonable if rusty Latin and my lovely purple jumper they will give it to a woman
author: patrick_kidd

text: One of my favourite bits of trivia relating to this: the last time the Commons sat on a Saturday was over the invasion of the Falklands. The session closed at 2.30pm, primarily so that MPs could watch the Grand National.
author: patrick_kidd

text: No 10 source has just seen the menu at the place @patrickkmaguire is taking him and would prefer Nandos.

text: Gardener's Question Time always has such excellent names on its panel. Bunny Guinness, Bob Flowerdew, Pippa Greenwood, Anne Swithinbank and now Kathy Clugston as the host. Names that just make you feel happy with life, even if I'm daunted by what they say.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Miss you!
author: patrick_kidd

In fact Glamorgan have won three. Northants, Gloucs and Somerset haven't won any

text: Oh they definitely did, around 1997 I think.
author: patrick_kidd

text: As I understand it, yes. It, of course, puts pressure on the government to follow the will of the House and find another solution, but if the EU won't grant an extension and we don't revoke or approve a deal then, in law, it's no deal
author: patrick_kidd

text: Good research! I think if nothing has changed by that stage he'll be St John of the Flipping Furious.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Not quite. Parliament voted not to leave without a deal but it has no legal force. If there is no deal by 29/3, nor an extension, and May decides not to revoke A50, then legally we leave without a deal and the vote the other week is irrelevant.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I think that if she were to be recalled, she would stop being paid at that point, not during the by-election that follows.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Is it just you two who haven't won it? Or is Northants also in the club?
author: patrick_kidd

text: Somerset may even have won the county championship before it is sorted out.
author: patrick_kidd

text: To be really famous you must be known by just one name of five letters, said Oscar Wilde (who qualifies twice). To Jesus, Moses, Elvis and Boris we can add Fiona, who is v well known in Peterborough, if not in a good way. Wrote this on the recall petition
author: patrick_kidd

text: It's 1,000 days since the Brexit referendum. My, how time has flown... I wonder if it will all be sorted out in another 1,000 days?
author: patrick_kidd

text: Argh! All those awful Oxford commas... And why no mention of the ability to bash out something readable after a long lunch?
author: patrick_kidd

text: I love a cheese scone.
author: patrick_kidd

text: It was ok but I’ve done much better. As good as I could do with not much material and legal restrictions on who I could talk to.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I’d not been there in more than ten years. Looks less like Manhattan than Onasanya led me to believe. Nice area round cathedral. Very quiet, though.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Or, as Bercow translates it frequently, "soothing medicament"
author: patrick_kidd

text: I understand Jacob Rees-Mogg already has Erskine May on tablet. Though when he says tablet, he means it's carved on stone...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Just wait until Erskine May comes to mobile...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Who knows these days... But no complaints yet.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I don't write the headlines. And I confess when I saw it this morning I was braced for people to take offence at it...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Lovely turn of phrase by @MattChorley on Tory MPs coming round to May’s deal: “People are coming across in the sort of numbers that might get S Javid to declare national emergency and have G Williamson threaten to send in the army, but nothing like the scale to have real impact”
author: patrick_kidd

text: Thank you. I miss writing them
author: patrick_kidd

text: You don't have to follow...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Universities are to Essex as county cricket teams are to Oxon.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Further to the below, in August 2017 the PM's spokesman said that Britain would leave the EU when Big Ben chimes midnight on 29/3/19. Is this the final loophole?
author: patrick_kidd

text: I just want it all to end
author: patrick_kidd

text: I'd have hoped that ITV could get bigger stars for the launch episode of An Audience with the Pope than Brendan Cole and Les Dennis. Maybe Olivia Colman and Danny Dyer weren't free.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Fair point on declaring what is constitutional (or at least precedented). Presumably you then opposed Bercow ignoring Erskine May to suit him in January? As for the title I write for, it endorsed Remain at the referendum but that probably doesn't suit your narrative either.
author: patrick_kidd

text: A long way from ancient but Mark Twain wrote a story in 1876 about how a man was cursed by an earworm and could only get rid of it by passing it on. Separately, I suspect Oedipus went mad because he couldn't get Baby Shark out of his head...
author: patrick_kidd

text: As long as we can agree that Giles Clarke was a bigger pompous arse than either of them!
author: patrick_kidd

text: 15.33 I'm afraid. Not sure what parliamentary precedents happened then.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Though I don't think I have ever really praised Cox's judgment, only the lemon-and-honey soothing quality of his voice and his verbiage. If only Bercow quoted from Milton more often...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Oh, sure, fair to call me a hypocrite on this, though it is something to do with both the role (Cox as Speaker would deserve more criticism) and the novelty (we've had a decade of Bercow being the way he is, only six months of even knowing who Cox is). But your point is fair.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I can see that point. Am happy to say Cox is a pompous arse, just one I enjoy watching a bit more. But, to go back to my former job, Giles Clarke and Kevin Pietersen are both arses, but different types of arse. Not that I think Cox is Clarke or Bercow KP, or even vice versa.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I think they are very different beasts. Yes, Cox is self-important (and so, viewing him purely as a D'Oyly Carte caricature, as was my job, I rather like him). Bercow is different. The emphasis is much more on the arse part with him. He is cocky and bumptious. Cox is just grand
author: patrick_kidd

text: Points of order on Bercow's statement lasted a few seconds over the hour. Eight minutes less than points of order when he over-ruled precedent (rather than upheld it, as today) before Christmas.
author: patrick_kidd

text: He's far worse than an arse.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Cox isn't patronising. He may have a superior tone but that's different. Bercow is withering and often downright rude.
author: patrick_kidd

text: nope
author: patrick_kidd

text: And, I hasten to add, I probably personally support Bercow's ends more than I do Cox's, but there is something about the former's pomposity that gets to me (give me Hoyle as Speaker any day). Cox's pomposity is just how people like him should be.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I enjoy following you and appreciate that you follow me and give me a kick if you think it is deserved. But they are different beasts. Cox's voice is fabulous, Bercow is an arse. I don't see how the two are incompatible.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Saves them from having to take a position on Brexit?
author: patrick_kidd

text: 1) Bercow doesn't have a fancy voice; 2) Bercow went to the University of Essex and, rather than be a QC, has done nothing more in his career than be a jumped-up pipsqueak; 3) Bercow is nonetheless still a pompous arse. You have to earn the right to be an arse, as Cox has.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Only with the public. And when do they ever get anything right?
author: patrick_kidd

text: With apologies to Brenda from Bristol, May should just call another general election. It probably won't change anything - she may even lose power, and few could say she deserves to keep it - but at least it would allow a new vote on whether to keep Bercow as Speaker.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Alan Clark used to say that if points of order went on for two minutes you should dash to the chamber because an almighty row has broken out. The response to Bercow declaring himself king has now been going on for 40 minutes.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Readers used to enjoy that every day.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Bercow is being a complete arse. Again. Lecturing the government front bench for looking at their phones rather than listening to his pronouncements. Talking about respect, not that he ever shows it.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Indeed.
author: patrick_kidd

text: I think there are two problems with that strategy: Francois is too slow-witted to get the joke and too thick-skinned for it to make a difference.
author: patrick_kidd

text: In-deeeed. As Bercow would say.
author: patrick_kidd

text: If you want to raise that with the chair...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Bercow has just made a joke about how he told Mark Francois when they first met in 1983 that he was intellectually knee high to a grasshopper. He made exactly the same joke in the Commons last week.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Oh NOW he believes in following precedent...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Doesn't look like the sort of city you could get up much of a speed. Too many stop lights
author: patrick_kidd

text: Presumably Ryanair then charged the other passengers for this in-flight entertainment
author: patrick_kidd

text: And worse than that, he doesn’t know what fulsomely means
author: patrick_kidd

text: “Genuinely stupid people never doubt for a second that they possess anything less than genius.” Wise words from @benschott in a piece for the PG Wodehouse Society journal on why Bertie Wooster is, to use a phrase of my old Latin master, not as green as he’s cabbage-looking
author: patrick_kidd

text: The thing is many English would be generous about the way Wales played today, worthy champions. Yet if England played that way there would be silence from Grant. And they call us arrogant...
author: patrick_kidd

text: Extraordinary match. Scotland were like the All Blacks in the second half. Every time they touched it they scored. Less than a minute spent in England’s 22 yet scored six tries. Wow.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Let’s not blame the ref. Wales outplayed Ireland in every area
author: patrick_kidd

text: The ref isn’t the difference. Wales doing a lot of things very well.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Where were you at altar-serving drop-off?
author: patrick_kidd

text: What a half by Wales. Clinical. Grand slam all but theirs. They came back from 16-0 to start the tournament, can’t see them blowing it.
author: patrick_kidd

text: That’s one hell of a start by Wales. Great dink by Anscombe. Bollocks, as the attorney general would say.
author: patrick_kidd

text: Right, with apologies to @GrantTucker @emmatimes2 @jcorrigangolf and other Welsh friends, come on Ireland!
author: patrick_kidd

text: Friendly-faced Al puts the curse to rest. My latest sketch from the Cheltenham Gold Cup. Features my aunt @PetaFoxall outdoing the great @robwrighttips as a tipster
author: patrick_kidd

text: 50 Greatest Bopara Innings?
author: patrick_kidd

text: Congratulations! Is 50 Greatest Test Matches next?
author: patrick_kidd

text: You’re just thinking of the pre-sales boost you’ll get by having him in a Rentoul list! When’s it out?
author: patrick_kidd

text: There is nothing I can do to change the only opinion that counts. I just have to keep doing other stuff well (Crufts last week, Cheltenham today) and maybe I'll get another go one day
author: patrick_kidd
